articles.headline: Designer Has Fan at Top, but Too Few at the Stores
articles.snippet: The designer Maria Pinto, whose creations were worn by Michelle Obama, explained why her shop abruptly closed.
articles.abstract: The designer Maria Pinto, whose creations were worn by Michelle Obama, explained why her shop abruptly closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Fashion and politics are seasonal and unpredictable, yet the two came together quite well here for the hometown designer Maria Pinto and Michelle Obama, whose first memorable bursts onto the national scene were often in Pinto creations.

articles.headline: Rare Breed Now: A Justice Who Wasn’t a Judge
articles.snippet: Unlike most front-runners for  a spot on the Supreme Court, Elena Kagan, the U.S. solicitor general, never served on the bench.
articles.abstract: Unlike most front-runners for  a spot on the Supreme Court, Elena Kagan, the U.S. solicitor general, never served on the bench.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 2001, at a boisterous annual banquet of The Harvard Law Review, a 40-year-old professor named Elena Kagan introduced the main speaker.

articles.headline: Democrats Reframe the Debate on Immigration
articles.snippet: The outline of a proposal for enforcement to stop future illegal immigration is likely to be the centerpiece of the discussion this year.
articles.abstract: The outline of a proposal for enforcement to stop future illegal immigration is likely to be the centerpiece of the discussion this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The outline for an immigration overhaul unveiled by Democratic senators this week lays down a new starting point for any national debate: tough immigration enforcement. But perhaps more significantly it reveals how politics have shifted on the contentious issue.

articles.headline: Gulf Coast Towns Brace as Huge Oil Slick Nears Marshes
articles.snippet: With oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico unabated and officials offering little hope that the flow could be contained soon, towns prepared for an imminent environmental disaster.
articles.abstract: With oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico unabated and officials offering little hope that the flow could be contained soon, towns prepared for an imminent environmental disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: COCODRIE, La. — Oil gushed into the Gulf of Mexico unabated Saturday, and officials conveyed little hope that the flow could be contained soon, forcing towns along the Gulf Coast to brace for what is increasingly understood to be an imminent environmental disaster.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Greek Wealth Is Everywhere but Tax Forms
articles.snippet: Studies have estimated that the government may be losing as much as $30 billion a year to tax evasion.
articles.abstract: Studies have estimated that the government may be losing as much as $30 billion a year to tax evasion.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In the wealthy, northern suburbs of this city, where summer temperatures often hit the high 90s, just 324 residents checked the box on their tax returns admitting that they owned pools.

articles.headline: Pope Reins In Catholic Order Tied to Abuse
articles.snippet: The moves against the Legionaries of Christ constituted the most direct action on sexual abuse since the most recent scandals have engulfed the church.
articles.abstract: The moves against the Legionaries of Christ constituted the most direct action on sexual abuse since the most recent scandals have engulfed the church.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday took control of the Legionaries of Christ, a powerful and wealthy Roman Catholic religious order whose founder, a friend of Pope John Paul II, was found to have molested seminarians and fathered several children.

articles.headline: Who Knew Bankruptcy Paid So Well?
articles.snippet: Bankruptcy specialists have been enjoying an unprecedented boom, but some fees are raising eyebrows.
articles.abstract: Bankruptcy specialists have been enjoying an unprecedented boom, but some fees are raising eyebrows.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORE than $263,000 for photocopies in four months. Over $2,100 in limousine rides by one partner in one month. And $48 just to leave a message. Explanations for these charges? Priceless.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: For Corn Syrup, the Sweet Talk Gets Harder
articles.snippet: Many Americans are trying to avoid high-fructose corn syrup, and more products are being made with sugar. But corn refiners haven’t given up trying to win over the public.
articles.abstract: Many Americans are trying to avoid high-fructose corn syrup, and more products are being made with sugar. But corn refiners haven’t given up trying to win over the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR much of 2009, Michael Locascio, an executive at ConAgra Foods, watched with concern as the bad news about high-fructose corn syrup kept coming.

articles.headline: Repaying Taxpayers With Their Own Cash
articles.snippet: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa says General Motors’ repayment of its federal bailout loan “appears to be nothing more than an elaborate TARP money shuffle.”
articles.abstract: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa says General Motors’ repayment of its federal bailout loan “appears to be nothing more than an elaborate TARP money shuffle.”
articles.lead_paragraph: AS we inch closer to a clearer understanding of the products and practices that unleashed the credit crisis of 2008, it’s becoming apparent that those seeking the whole truth are still outnumbered by those aiming to obscure it. This is the case not only on Wall Street but also in Washington.

articles.headline: BP Moves to Fix a Leak as Obama Warns of Damage
articles.snippet: BP prepared to install a shutoff valve on one of three leaks gushing from an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.abstract: BP prepared to install a shutoff valve on one of three leaks gushing from an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — BP prepared Monday to install a shutoff valve on one of three leaks gushing from an oil spill off the coast of New Orleans, in a bid to stem what President Obama called a "potentially unprecedented environmental disaster."
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Henry Fountain

articles.headline: United and Continental Said to Agree to Merge
articles.snippet: The airlines agreed to a $3 billion merger that creates the world’s biggest airline, people familiar with the talks said.
articles.abstract: The airlines agreed to a $3 billion merger that creates the world’s biggest airline, people familiar with the talks said.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Airlines and Continental Airlines agreed Sunday to a $3 billion merger that would create the world’s biggest airline, according to people briefed on the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In New York, a Tech Incubator Becomes a Hub of Collaboration
articles.snippet: Betaworks has fostered some big hits, like TweetDeck and Bit.ly, but it is trying to grow carefully, with a symbiotic group of companies.
articles.abstract: Betaworks has fostered some big hits, like TweetDeck and Bit.ly, but it is trying to grow carefully, with a symbiotic group of companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2008, before most people knew what a tweet was, Iain Dodsworth, a programmer in London, cobbled together a software tool that reorganized his jumbled Twitter stream into neat columns. He named it TweetDeck.

articles.headline: A Lost iPhone Shows Apple’s Churlish Side
articles.snippet: Apple is exhibiting a spectacular amount of tone-deafness in its handling of the case of the lost iPhone prototype.
articles.abstract: Apple is exhibiting a spectacular amount of tone-deafness in its handling of the case of the lost iPhone prototype.
articles.lead_paragraph: Journalists are already getting warmed up for the next big Apple event, the Worldwide Developers Conference in June, where they will most likely get a look at the next generation of the iPhone.

articles.headline: Tylenol, Generics and Trust
articles.snippet: After a wide recall of children’s drugs, many parents are questioning the value, and sense of security, when buying a name brand over cheaper generic medicines.
articles.abstract: After a wide recall of children’s drugs, many parents are questioning the value, and sense of security, when buying a name brand over cheaper generic medicines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is a brand-name drug synonymous with quality?

articles.headline: Audiences, and Hollywood, Flock to Smartphones
articles.snippet: The mobile-video audience is tiny, but TV and film companies foresee an increasingly wireless world — and don’t want to be left out of the picture.
articles.abstract: The mobile-video audience is tiny, but TV and film companies foresee an increasingly wireless world — and don’t want to be left out of the picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might be hard to imagine watching “The Office” on a screen no bigger than a business card. But tens of thousands of people — by the most conservative estimate — are already doing just that.

articles.headline: Deflation Could Stall Efforts to Revive Greece
articles.snippet: There are serious questions about whether the harsh austerity measures Greece committed to are sustainable.
articles.abstract: There are serious questions about whether the harsh austerity measures Greece committed to are sustainable.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Greece, effectively bankrupt and with a European gun to its head, committed itself to years of austerity on Sunday when it signed a financial bailout deal with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

articles.headline: Greece Takes Its Bailout, but Doubts for the Region Persist
articles.snippet: The bailout by the International Monetary Fund and Greece’s European partners calls for as much as $146 billion in loans over the next three years.
articles.abstract: The bailout by the International Monetary Fund and Greece’s European partners calls for as much as $146 billion in loans over the next three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece announced on Sunday that it had reached agreement on a long-delayed financial rescue package that would require years of painful belt-tightening, but the deal might not be enough to stop the spread of economic contagion to other European countries with mounting debts and troubled economies.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Abuse Case Offers a View of the Vatican’s Politics
articles.snippet: The abuse case against one of the most powerful priests in the Roman Catholic Church remained stalled for years.
articles.abstract: The abuse case against one of the most powerful priests in the Roman Catholic Church remained stalled for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two former Mexican seminarians had gone to the Vatican in 1998 to personally deliver a case recounting decades of sexual abuse by one of the most powerful priests in the Roman Catholic Church, the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado.
articles.byline: By Daniel J. Wakin and James C. McKinley Jr

articles.headline: Big Paydays for the Chiefs in the Media
articles.snippet: Top executives at media companies continued to reel in multimillion-dollar pay packages in 2009, a year of widespread cost-cutting for the industry.
articles.abstract: Top executives at media companies continued to reel in multimillion-dollar pay packages in 2009, a year of widespread cost-cutting for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The media industry may be going through some rough times, with the landscape changing day to day, but at least one aspect is business as usual: big paydays for the people at the top.

articles.headline: In United-Continental Deal, Birth of a Behemoth
articles.snippet: The deal, completed in three weeks, gives the airlines the muscle to fend off low-cost rivals at home and to take on foreign carriers abroad.
articles.abstract: The deal, completed in three weeks, gives the airlines the muscle to fend off low-cost rivals at home and to take on foreign carriers abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffery A. Smisek has held the top job at Continental Airlines for just five months — long enough to show he is not going to follow quietly in the steps of his predecessors.
